reviewText: This DVD consists of a 37-minute film made for Colonial Williamsburg in the 50's, and two short documentaries: one on the restoration of the film, and the second an introduction to Colonial Williamsburg.The acting in the little movie is pretty wooden, but the costumes look great. It's primarily of interest as Colonial Williamsburg nostalgia, although it is interesting that the "patriot" in the title has many misgivings about turning against England. Most movies about this period seem to show everyone as having already made up their mind.Jack Lord and John McGiver (in a brief cameo) are the only stars you'll recognize. Bernard Herrmann did the music!The two little documentaries are a nice complement to the film, but are a little too brief.At one point members of the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation received copies of this free as a membership benefit.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Beautiful with a nice booklet...Interesting information about film restoration.Except for the pictures from the original filming, the commentary is dull and monotonous.
summary: Williamsburg The Story Of A Patriot

reviewerName: J S Lasher "Fifth Continent Australia Pty Ltd."
reviewText: This is the longest running film in the history of cinema. The DVD, which features the recent digital restoration of the original VistaVision film and sound elements by Robert Harris (who also worked on similar restorations of "Spartacus", "My Fair Lady", "Lawrence of Arabia" and "Vertigo"), is also notable for the rich colours and the 3-track stereo sound mix, each of which have been enriched in this excellent transfer.Pay particular attention to the fine music score by the legendary Bernard Herrmann.Another film due for a Blu-ray upgrade.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this because it had Jack Lord in it and I was a big fan of Jack Lord back in the day of Stoney Burke. My family had been to Williamsburg about every other year for our summer vacation and I remember seeing this short film in the theatre there before touring the facilities. It brought back fond memories. Although it is a short documentary on the beginnings of our country it still holds its charm. If you are actually looking for a typical movie this is not what you are looking for but if you remember the shortie as a kid-- it is a memory reminder.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I taught history for 38 years before I retired and back when airfares weren't exorbitant we had a program that allowed 10th graders to go on "Highway History".  It was a program that was done in lieu of requiring the normal U.S. History course in their Junior year.  We had three weeks of intensive in-class instruction followed by a nineteen day trip to historical sites on the east coast, ending with a five day stay in Washington DC.  At the end of the trip we had a final week of classwork.  It was a lot of fun, a lot of work because the students had to do assignments all along the way covering what they saw and experienced.  We went to Williamsburg and this movie was (and still is) shown at the visitor's center.  It served as a prolog to the student's visit to the tour site which was refurbished by John D. Rockefeller II and his money to its glory at the time of the Revolution.  The film does a good job of showing the visitor what they will be seeing as they tour, giving a history lesson in the process.  It isn't en epic film but it does the job by showing the events through the eyes of John Fry (Jack Lord), a planter weighing the pros and cons of the gathering storm of independence.  The House of Burgesses, The governor's mansion and the Michie Tavern where the colonial leaders met are all shown.This is really more of a curiosity because it has played at Williamsburg since 1957 continually.  Several years ago someone realized that the film was a ragged, faded mess and had it restored.  A fine job too, crisp and bright and done with great care.  It won't be everyone's cup of tea, but as a  reminiscence of a retired teacher it was fun to see.  It was also fun to hear kids whisper "Look! There's Steve McGarrett!" when a younger Jack Lord came on the screen.A pretty good history lesson, well photographed, directed by George Seaton.  Fun to see if you have a sentimental streak.  I plead guilty to that...
summary: Williamsburg The Story of A Patriot
